comment-body: AI-generated content will flood the internet, making it impossible to find real human-created works.

AI companies should pay licensing fees when training on copyrighted content, just like musicians pay to sample a song.

If an AI-generated image mimics a specific artist’s style, that should count as copyright infringement.

Creators should have an opt-in system for AI training, not an opt-out one.

AI-generated content shouldn’t be legally protected by copyright—only human-made work should be.
If AI replaces human artists, it will kill the incentive to create original work in the first place.
Small creators will lose their livelihoods if AI can generate art and writing that mimics them perfectly for free.
Big AI companies are profiting off artists’ work without consent or compensation—this is digital colonialism.
Copyright should focus on AI outputs, not training data—if the AI generates something too similar to an existing work, that’s infringement.
Generative AI should be treated like a remix or derivative work, meaning it gets limited copyright but not full ownership.
Rather than banning AI training on copyrighted work, artists should be able to set their own royalty rates.
Even if AI-generated works are legal, there’s a moral argument that profiting from someone else’s work without credit is wrong.
We need transparency—AI models should disclose their training data, but banning AI from learning entirely isn’t practical.
Creators should have an opt-in system for AI training, not an opt-out one.
There should be a public licensing system where AI companies pay into a collective fund that compensates creators.
Copyright law wasn’t designed for AI, and trying to apply it rigidly will only lead to unnecessary legal battles.
Regulating AI training too harshly will slow down innovation and make it impossible for smaller companies to compete.
The idea of owning a style is absurd—artists are always influenced by others.
AI should be able to learn from any publicly available data without restriction, just like a person can.
Training AI models on copyrighted works should be considered fair use, just like humans learning from books and movies.
AI-generated books and articles should disclose which copyrighted materials influenced their output.
AI-generated content shouldn’t be legally protected by copyright—only human-made work should be.
If an AI-generated image mimics a specific artist’s style, that should count as copyright infringement.
AI companies should pay licensing fees when training on copyrighted content, just like musicians pay to sample a song.
The panic over AI using copyrighted material reflects artists' psychological investment in control rather than a genuine economic concern.
Human art's value in the AI era lies in lived experience, not legal protection.
AI reveals copyright's true purpose: artificial scarcity in a world of natural abundance.
The age of AI demonstrates that copyright was always a retrograde and elitist attempt at intellectual enclosure.
Rules for how creators opt-out of AI training should be the same worldwide to make compliance easier.
Forcing AI companies to reveal exactly what data they trained on would harm innovation and business competition.
If we need permission for all training data, small AI companies won't be able to compete with giants like Google or Microsoft.
A simple system where creators can choose not to have their work used strikes the right balance for everyone.
If news organizations aren't paid when AI systems use our content, quality journalism will become financially unsustainable.
AI companies, not publishers, should be responsible for building the technical systems that respect our content rights.
As a creator, I should have the final say on whether my work is used to train AI that might replace my job.
Knowing my work was used for AI training is pointless if I can't afford to take legal action against misuse.
University research should have more freedom to use data than commercial AI companies.
Content created by AI shouldn't get copyright protection, as this would limit how researchers can use and build on AI outputs.
The profits made from AI systems should be shared with the creators whose work made those systems possible.
Small creators and businesses need a simple way to protect their content that doesn't require technical expertise.
Good AI rules need to balance protecting creators with allowing technological progress that benefits society.
Removing copyright for AI-generated content would help prevent human artists from being undercut by machine-made work.
Unclear rules about AI training data could leave businesses that use AI tools facing unexpected copyright lawsuits.
If AI companies have to pay more for training data, those costs will ultimately be passed on to businesses and consumers.
Courts can't effectively handle AI copyright disputes without clearer laws from Parliament.
The current rules for computer-generated works create more legal confusion than clarity and should be reconsidered.
UK rules on AI and copyright should align with major trading partners to keep our tech industry competitive.
Policies that respect both creator rights and innovation will make the UK a global leader in responsible AI.
AI profits needs to be distributed more widely
consider introducing a universal basic income for creators who can then choose how to monetise their works or not beyond that
AI companies should pay a fee for using an artists work. to enforce this all training data usage should be transparent
Copyright compensation is an opportunity for a new market for original human works.
Training models on copyrighted material should be allowed for short term or specific use, but large portions should not be regurgitated
There's a moral argument that profiting from someone else's work without compensation is wrong
copyright is a way of gatekeeping ideas. we should change the paradigm of thinking about content to move towards open source
AI and human generated content will meld and blend, changing the concept of creation.
Human art's value in the AI era lies in lived experience, AND legal protection.
Human art's value in the AI era lies in lived experience, and legal protection.
Hello this is a test test test test
Bernie for president
We need a balanced approach that does not guarantee income for creators but insures there is an incentive for human creation.
It's impractical to add copyright laws to AI, OpenAI etc have already broken the watershed and we're past the point of no return
Underpinning all of these it’s hard to disentangle normative arguments of an ideal world with reality of global competition - the UK’s small
Soon, pretty much everything is at least part-AI-generated, so it makes little sense to separate human- and AI-generated content
Our solution to this problem may not come from existing legal solutions like licensing, royalties, or basic income. New ideas may be needed
